node.text:
James Suckling discusses Napa Valley’s 2018 vintage with winemaker Andy Erickson of Favia Erickson Wines. 

Andy says that the wines are “high resolution” in their structure and intensity. “I feel like there’s so much energy in our ‘18s, and the aromatics just speak to the sites, which I really love,” he says. 

The Favia Cabernet Sauvignon Coombsville 2018 is among the wines James points to as representative of the vintage’s “incredible balance.” You can watch their tasting of it in this Zoom clip. 

#California #CalifornianWines #NapaValley #NapaValleyWines #FaviaWines @faviawines #AndyErickson #wine #winetasting #winelover #wineaddict #vino #winenerd #winestagram #winery #instawine #winelife #wineoclock #winemaker #winewinewine #winegeek #jamessuckling #wineblog

node.text:
James talks with Isaac, Eduardo and Manuel Muga, the third generation of La Rioja winery Bodegas Muga, about their latest releases. Muga's flagship wines are reds, including their Reserva and Seleccion Especial. 

"When we think the vintage hasn't been perfect for us in terms of conditions, then we are going to focus all our efforts either on one wine, which is the Reserva or ... on the Seleccion Especial," Eduardo Muga says.

node.text:
How does Napa Valley winemaker Andy Erickson produce such a fruit-forward, multi-varietal red for less than $40? Find out what went into the making of the Leviathan 2019 in this Zoom snippet.

node.text:
Under the watchful eye of patriarch Gianni, Poderi Gianni Gagliardo makes focused, precise wines – particularly, single-vineyard Barolos – in the Langhe. Gianni started making wines back in the 1970s, however, it wasn’t until the 1980s that his wines came into their own. Today, the winemaking responsibilities are in the hands of his three sons: Stefano, Alberto and Paolo. The winery owns many small plots of land that are all distributed in five different villages with varying soil compositions. We especially like the younger wines here but don’t miss their special Barolos that are released after an extended aging in bottle (Archivio Storico): they show the wonder in aged Barolos. 

In this video Stefano Gagliardo presents Barolo del Comune di La Morra Poderi, shown at the Great Wines of the World Autumn Edition in Hong Kong this month.

node.text:
Anselmo Guerrieri Gonzaga, the owner of Italian winery Tenuta San Leonardo, sits down with James to talk about the history and current winemaking style of San Leonardo. "All our red wines are still only made in concrete vats," Anselmo says. "We do not use any stainless steel. There is no refrigeration, no heating, no [commercial] yeasts, we only use indigenous yeasts." He adds: "I am not against technology, it's just that in this area, the climate is so fine that it's easy to make red wines, and we can do them in a proper way to respect the terroir."

node.text:
In this tasting of Vega Sicilia's 2017 and 2018 releases, James speaks with Gonzalo Iturriaga, the head winemaker at Macàn and Vega Sicilia, and Pablo Alvarez, the owner and CEO of Vega Sicilia.

Gonzalo explains that 2017 was one of the more challenging vintages recently, due to the incredibly hot weather that they experienced in Toro, Spain, but that the 2018 vintage is "more elegantly balanced," which is why he favors the latter vintage. Check out the video to hear their opinions on the current winemaking trend in Spain and to learn more about Vega Sicilia's latest releases.

node.text:
Artadi owner/winemaker Carlos Lopez de Lacalle says the 2018 vintage came from a warm summer with a slightly cold September. "From that we got all this fresh, elegant, ripe fruit aromas with great balance and a lot of tension." James says the Artadi 2018 wines are good now, but asks Carlos how he thinks they will age. "For us, a wine that ages needs to be drinkable when it's young," Carlos says, adding that he's certain the 2018s will age, given their ripe tannins and higher acidity. "Now if you taste your wines, if you want to make comparisons it's like Burgundy now," James said of the 2018s compared with 10 years ago. "It's really just fresh, and really fine tannins ... and you can see the differences in all the different crus, and I think that's really exciting."

node.text:
JamesSuckling.com has always promoted village and sub-appellations for Chianti Classicos, and we are happy the rule changes pertaining to the sub-appellations are taking effect. 

Our video series on Chianti Classicos covers each comune, and includes interviews with owners, enologists and members of the Chianti Classico Consortium. It looks at their wines, their comunes, the history and the future of Chianti Classico. 

Of all the comunes of Chianti Classico, the two we'll meet in episode eight are without a doubt the least known of all: Tavarnelle Val di Pesa and Poggibonsi. Given their relative obscurity, we thought it a good idea to group them together. Most of the land in these two comunes isn't actually Chianti Classico at all, extending instead into the realms of just Chianti. Both also give home to the largest and most urbanized towns of the region. 

Nevertheless, there are one or two excellent producers who fight against the odds. One is Johannes Davaz, a Swiss whose relatives still make pinot near Lichtenstein. Today he owns his own small but first-class property in Tavarnelle Val di Chianti Classico called "Poggio Al Sole." He explains how it can be difficult making wine in an unknown area, especially since he feels his wines belong more to the much better-known comune of Greve. 

In the comune of Poggibonsi, there are only two serious wine producers. Cinciano is one of them, but as commercial director Angelo Dalbello explains, the comune has always been important for other reasons – back in medieval times it was an important stop on the ancient Via Francigena, one of the great ways of the ancient world. 

Similarly to Tavarnelle, it's an especially frustrating situation for Cinciano because their winery actually sits on a hill above the large town, where, as Angelo asserts, ventilation, exposure and soils are all top quality. Angelo is looking to promote his brand first and foremost. He makes a good point that when it comes to quality – ultimately it's up to the producer to prove his worth. 

#Italy #ItalianWine #ChiantiClassico #ChiantiClassicoDiaries #wine #winenerd #winestagram #winery #winemaker #winewinewine #winegeek #jamessuckling

node.text:
James recently tasted the Laurent-Perrier Champagne Grand Siècle Grand Cuvée N.23 NV Magnum, which impressed him so much he said to Lucie Pereyre de Nonacourt, who represents the fourth generation at Champagne Laurent-Perrier, and Edouard Cossy, the company's global director: "The aromas were amazing. Honestly, I can't think of a more beautiful Champagne with the aromas... that sort of brioche and tarte au limon." 

Lucie tells the story of how her grandfather founded the Laurent-Perrier Champagne Grand Siècle Grand Cuvée. When he became director of the house, he realized he had to have a prestige cuvée. He based the creation of his cuvée on a unique blend, which would take the champagne further in terms of quality and thus achieve his goal of recreating the perfect year – "one that nature cannot provide." 

Check out their conversation now to learn more about the Grand Siècle Grand Cuvée N.23 NV Magnum and when to expect its release.

node.text:
American Pinot Noir producer Adam Lee wears many hats: he was a co-founder of Siduri Wines (and remains a consultant and winemaker), founded the Clarice Wine Company, and co-founded Beau Marchais Wine with famed vintner Philippe Cambie. 

In this chat with JamesSuckling.com Associate Editor and Taster Claire Nesbitt, Adam talks about his approach in making pinot through whole-cluster fermentation and why he varied whole-cluster percentages for the 2017-19 vintages. Claire also asks Adam for his thoughts on the uncertainty of the final product and whether whole-cluster fermentation can affect a wine negatively, to which Adam responds: "Yes, there is a risk you could have unripe stems ... [but] one of the things I have found on stem ripeness is it has to do with the length of hang time and does not correlate with sugar maturity." 

Check out the rest of their conversation for more of Adam's thoughts on pinots and their future on the West Coast.

node.text:
WILLAMETTE VALLEY PINOT NOIRS UNDER $40 FEATURE: PURPLE HANDS WINERY 

Purple Hands Winery is a family-run winery in Willamette Valley, Oregon, where owners Cody (also the winemaker) and Marque Wright focus on continuing the legacy of wine quality that the Cody family has laid out over the past 40 years. 

Their Pinot Noir Willamette Valley Lone Oak Ranch 2019 (93 points) is plush and fleshy, with rounded, ripe tannins, and a juicy core of ripe berries. It was also one of our picks for Great Value Willamette Valley pinot noirs under $40. To see the others, check out the report by Associate Editor Zekun Shuai for free by clicking on the link in the bio or visiting JamesSuckling.com.

node.text:
Saturday afternoon's masterclass on Argentina's move toward finesse and elegance showcased a lineup of nine wines from 2015: a mild, cool vintage that produced wines with balance and fresh acidity. JamesSuckling.com taster Claire Nesbitt led guests at @jamessucklingwinecentral through a selection of eight malbecs and a cabernet franc from Mendoza, the heart of Argentina's wine industry.
 
Guests enjoyed discovering the concentration and power of malbecs from old vines and high altitudes, alongside the drinkability and supple texture of the Argentinian expression of this 2000-year-old grape. Look out for single-vineyard and even single-parcel wines from top producers, with a drive toward increasing finesse, precision and ageability.

node.text:
Today’s first Masterclass @jamessucklingwinecentral and part of the Great Wine of the World Edition 3 focused on how Provence wineries have become the masters of rosé. Led by JamesSuckling.com Tasting Team member Kevin Davy, a native of Provence, the masterclass featured different styles of rosé produced by two renowned estates.
 
Attendees discovered more about what makes rosé so special, its origin and variations as well as the habits and customs of where it’s made. Guests enjoyed the freshness and consistent quality of the dry, fruity rosés; the estate rosés showed precision, a sense of terroir and a great versatility while the iconic cuvées, or gastronomic rosés, impressed with their balance, complexity and unique character.
 
As Provence masters rosé, it keeps innovation and progress at the center of its work. The development and increased launches of premium gastronomic cuvées helps build its reputation and also enhances the image of Provence rosés as superior quality wines.

node.text:
The Wendouree Shiraz Clare Valley 2018 was the #2-ranked wine on our list of Top 100 Wines of Australia in 2020, and with good reason. 

The JamesSuckling.com Tasting Team called it “without question the best release of this wine in almost 30 years,” hailing from a vintage that delivered exceptional quality across all of Wendouree’s 2020 releases. 

Coming from a single parcel planted in 1919, this 100-pointer “has a brand of seamless length, balance and majesty that is underwritten by meticulously tended very old vines combined with an attentive, traditional winemaking approach.” 

For more details on our Top 100 Wines of Australia 2020, and to see more of our Top 100 lists, click on the link in the bio or visit JamesSuckling.com.

node.text:
Leave it to Moet Hennessy to take the lead in China with Ao Yun, a high-altitude winery in the Himalayas. The luxury brand behind Dom Perignon, Chateau Cheval Blanc and Chateau d’Yquem (among others) was drawn to the mild climate and intense sunlight of this spot in Yunnan province. The vineyards are between 2,200 and 2,600 meters high and comprise around 30 hectares of mostly cabernet sauvignon, merlot and cabernet franc. The vintages here just seem to get better and better. Recent years show outstanding tannin complexity and resolution. It’s anyone’s guess just how good these organically farmed wines might get. 

Here, Maxence Dulou, the winemaker at Ao Yun, presents Ao Yun Shangri-La 2017.

node.text:
THE BEAUTY OF AUSTRIAN REDS 

The latest Weekly Tasting Report brings to light some slightly under-the-radar wines from Austria, among them the near-perfect, 99-point Moric Blaufrankisch Burgenland Lutzmannsburg Alte Reben 2019, which is extremely graceful and refined, and the youthful, complex and energetic Dorli Muhr Blaufrankisch Carnuntum Ried Spitzerberg-Spitzer El 2019 (98 points), shown here. 

James is a fan of the Moric and Dorli Muhr reds, particularly from such grapes as Blaufrankisch. He loves their drinkability and freshness with deep dark fruit. They have beautiful balance and transparency. 

Check out the other Austrian wines that shone in the latest Weekly Tasting Report now at JamesSuckling.com.

node.text:
JUST PUBLISHED ON THE JAMESSUCKLING.COM WINE PODCAST: NEW RELEASES FROM BODEGAS MUGA 

In a recent chat with Isaac, Eduardo and Manuel Muga, the third generation of La Rioja winery Bodegas Muga, James tastes  several Muga offerings, including the flagship Muga Rioja Reserva 2018, which still has four months to go in bottle before it is released to the market. 

James calls it "really delicious already," but adds that in four more months, "it'll just be perfect then." 

Here are the other Muga wines they tasted: 

Muga Cava Casa Conde de Haro Reserva Brut 2018 
Muga Cava Conde de Haro Brut Rosé 2016 
Muga Rioja Blanco 2020 
Muga Rioja Rosado Flor de Muga 2020 
Muga Rioja Selección Especial Reserva 2005 
Muga Rioja Prado Enea Gran Reserva 2014
